FacilityName: City of Greenwood, MS - Wastewater Treatment Plant

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Other Nonhazardous Waste Treatment and Disposal

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies of the City of Greenwood, Mississippi POTW, which is a stationary source of chlorine are:  To comply with this risk management plan in the utilization of chlorine to treat municipal waste water, maintain a qualified operation and hazard response trained work force, implement preventative maintenance program and provide community awareness.



This facility is a publicly operated waste water treatment plant that provides service to approximately 16,000 residences and a variety of businesses and small industries.  This plant utilizes holding ponds, digester, and a clarifier in cleaning waste water for ultimate discharge into the Yazoo River.  The plant currently has an emergency response plan prepared by Victor L. Stokes and employees receive periodic safety training and procedures for responding to an emergency release.  At any one time there can be as many as twelve - 2,000 lb. steel cylinders containing chlorine.  Chlorine is used in the waste water treatment process to purify the effluent before discharge.  Chlorine in the cylinder is compressed to a liquid state and when discharged through a regulator into the effluent stream becomes gas and is absorbed into the water sterilization.  The CASE# for chlorine is 7782-50-6.  The regulated level for chlorine Is 2,500 lbs.; therefore this facility must have a risk management plan.   



This facility implements an accident release prevention program.  This program includes safety training and operating procedures to respond to any release.  Handling cylinders so that no full cylinder will be moved over another full cylinder, therefore greatly minimizing the worse case scenario of two cylinders impacting with both rupturing.  Also the lift height for chlorine filled cylinders is reduced to less than a foot, further minimizing the chance of a release.  The alternate release scenario of a minor release (1-2 lbs.), when changing valves on cylinders, can be c

ontrolled by using a ventilation system and automatic shut off valves will eliminate down stream releases from system leaks.



The five year accident history shows no releases occurred during this period.



The emergency response program utilizes the plan Re-Act Team working with the Fire Department and the City Emergency Management Coordinator to establish a command post to treat a major incident.



Planned changes to improve safety consist of the following:  Frequent replacement of the gas supply lines to the effluent, the more logical and safe procedure for handling chlorine filled cylinders and the availability of SCBA should the operator be required to close a cylinder valve in an alternative release scenario.
